title: Quiz 7: Comprehensive Final Exam
description: The final integration assessment covering all 18 chapters. This exam tests your ability to connect concepts across different body systems, apply physiological principles to clinical scenarios, and demonstrate a holistic understanding of human anatomy and physiology.

questions.question: Which of the following scenarios best illustrates the principle of Homeostasis via Negative Feedback?

options.text: During labor, oxytocin release stimulates stronger uterine contractions, which stimulates more oxytocin release.
Blood clotting platelets release chemicals to attract more platelets to the injury site.
A drop in blood pressure triggers a reflex that increases heart rate and constricts vessels to raise pressure back to normal.
Digestion of protein in the stomach triggers the release of more acid to digest more protein.

questions.explanation: Negative feedback REVERSES a deviation from the set point (e.g., low BP -> correction to raise BP). Labor and clotting are examples of positive feedback (amplification).
questions.hint: Look for the example where the body tries to 'correct' a change back to normal.

questions.question: A patient arrives in Hypovolaemic Shock due to severe haemorrhage. Which of the following physiological compensatory mechanisms will occur? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Release of Renin by the kidneys

questions.explanation: To maintain BP and perfusion: Sympathetic system increases HR and constricts vessels (pale skin). Kidneys release Renin (RAAS) and Pituitary releases ADH to retain fluid.
questions.hint: The body wants to save water and keep blood pressure up.

questions.question: Match the organ system with its primary contribution to maintaining blood pH (Acid-Base Balance):

pairs.right: Rapid, temporary chemical binding of excess H+

questions.explanation: Lungs blow off acid (CO2). Kidneys excrete fixed acids/bases (long term). Blood buffers act instantly.
questions.hint: Lungs handle gas; Kidneys handle ions.

questions.question: Trace the path of a molecule of Urea from its production to its excretion.

items.text: Bloodstream (Inferior Vena Cava -> Heart -> Aorta -> Renal Artery)

questions.explanation: Urea is made in the Liver -> Transported by Blood -> Filtered by Kidneys -> Excreted in Urine.
questions.hint: Start with where proteins are broken down.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the 'Respiratory Membrane' where gas exchange occurs?

options.text: The ciliated epithelium of the trachea
The fused basement membranes of the alveolar epithelium and the capillary endothelium
The pleural membranes surrounding the lungs
The mucus layer lining the bronchi

questions.explanation: The respiratory membrane consists of the simple squamous epithelium of the alveolus and the endothelium of the capillary, fused together to be extremely thin for diffusion.
questions.hint: It must be very thin and involves blood vessels and air sacs.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ nervous system division is responsible for the 'Rest and Digest' response, involving the ___BLANK___ nerve which supplies many thoracic and abdominal organs.
questions.explanation: Parasympathetic = Rest and Digest. The Vagus nerve (CN X) carries 75% of parasympathetic outflow.
questions.hint: Para- means beside/beyond. The nerve name means 'Wanderer'.

questions.question: Which hormones are involved in the regulation of Calcium levels in the blood? (Select two)
questions.explanation: PTH raises blood calcium (from bone). Calcitonin lowers blood calcium (to bone).
questions.hint: One from the thyroid, one from the parathyroid.

questions.question: A patient with liver failure (cirrhosis) presents with significant oedema and ascites. What is the primary physiological cause?

richContent.content:
Lab Results:

  • Albumin: Low
  • Clotting Factors: Low
  • Bilirubin: High

options.text: Increased hydrostatic pressure due to heart failure
Reduced plasma osmotic pressure due to lack of albumin production
Increased capillary permeability due to infection

questions.explanation: The liver produces plasma proteins (albumin). Failure leads to hypoalbuminaemia, reducing osmotic pressure, so fluid leaks into tissues (oedema) and abdomen (ascites).
questions.hint: Albumin acts like a 'magnet' keeping water in the blood.

questions.question: Match the tissue type with its specific location:

pairs.right: Ends of long bones / C-rings of trachea

questions.explanation: Transitional stretches (bladder). Ciliated cleans air (trachea). Simple squamous allows diffusion (lungs). Hyaline provides smooth support (joints/airway).
questions.hint: Which one needs to stretch when full?

questions.question: What is the term for the passive movement of water across a semipermeable membrane from a dilute solution to a more concentrated solution?
questions.explanation: Osmosis is the specific diffusion of water.
questions.hint: O__osis.

questions.question: During the Cardiac Cycle, what causes the 'Lub' (first heart sound)?

options.text: Closure of the Aortic and Pulmonary valves
Closure of the Atrioventricular (Mitral and Tricuspid) valves

questions.explanation: S1 ('Lub') is caused by the closure of the AV valves at the start of ventricular systole. S2 ('Dup') is the closure of semilunar valves.
questions.hint: It happens when the ventricles start to squeeze.

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristics of the SYMPATHETIC nervous system response? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Fight or Flight: Airway opens, Heart beats faster, Energy (glucose) released. Digestion stops, Pupils dilate (to see danger).
questions.hint: What do you need to run from a lion?

questions.question: Order the layers of the digestive tract wall from INNERMOST (lumen) to OUTERMOST.
questions.explanation: Food touches the Mucosa. Then Submucosa (vessels). Then Muscle (movement). Then Serosa (skin of the organ).
questions.hint: M-S-M-S.

questions.question: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus is characterized by insulin resistance in body cells, while insulin production remains normal.
questions.explanation: FALSE. This describes Type 2. Type 1 is an autoimmune destruction of beta cells leading to NO insulin production.
questions.hint: Type 1 usually requires insulin injections immediately.

questions.question: Which region of the brain controls body temperature, appetite, and the pituitary gland?
questions.explanation: The Hypothalamus is the main homeostatic center.
questions.hint: It is 'below' the thalamus.

questions.question: Match the digestive secretion with its source:
questions.explanation: Acid=Stomach. Bile=Liver. Insulin=Pancreas. Saliva=Mouth.
questions.hint: Where is pH very low?

questions.question: Review the clinical signs. Which condition is most likely?

richContent.content:
Signs:
- Tachycardia (Fast heart rate)
- Heat intolerance
- Weight loss despite increased appetite
- Exophthalmos (bulging eyes)

questions.explanation: These are classic signs of Hyperthyroidism (specifically Graves' due to the eyes). Metabolism is running too fast.
questions.hint: Everything is speeding up/heating up.

questions.question: The specific type of cell division that results in four genetically unique haploid gametes is called ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Meiosis produces sex cells (gametes). Mitosis produces identical body cells.
questions.hint: Not Mitosis.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of the SKELETON? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The skeleton supports, protects, moves, stores minerals, and makes blood. Vitamin D is synthesized by the SKIN.
questions.hint: Bones do more than just hold you up.

questions.question: What is the term for the process of gas exchange between the blood in the capillaries and the body tissues?
questions.explanation: Internal respiration happens at the tissue level. External respiration happens in the lungs.
questions.hint: Respiration happening 'inside' the body tissues.

questions.question: Order the structures of the respiratory tree from largest to smallest.
questions.explanation: Trachea -> Bronchi -> Bronchioles -> Alveoli.
questions.hint: Windpipe to Air sacs.

questions.question: In the menstrual cycle, what is the role of the hormone Progesterone?

options.text: Maintains the thickened endometrium for pregnancy

questions.explanation: Progesterone (produced by the Corpus Luteum) is the 'pro-gestation' hormone. It keeps the uterus ready for a baby. A drop in progesterone causes menstruation.
questions.hint: PRO-Gestation (pregnancy).

questions.question: Match the immunity type with its description:

pairs.right: Specific, delayed defense with memory (e.g., antibodies)
Body makes its own antibodies (infection or vaccine)
Body receives antibodies (breast milk or injection)

questions.explanation: Innate=Born with. Adaptive=Learned. Active=You make it. Passive=You are given it.
questions.hint: Active requires effort (making antibodies).

questions.question: What is the primary function of the Lymph Nodes?

options.text: To filter lymph and facilitate immune responses (phagocytosis/antibody production)

questions.explanation: Lymph nodes are filters packed with immune cells to clean the lymph before it returns to the blood.
questions.hint: Like a water filter for the immune system.

questions.question: The pulmonary artery carries oxygenated blood to the heart.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The Pulmonary Artery carries DEOXYGENATED blood AWAY from the heart to the lungs. It is the only artery (along with umbilical) that carries blue blood.
questions.hint: Arteries go Away. Pulmonary goes to lungs (to GET oxygen).

questions.question: Which of the following are associated with the 'Flight or Flight' response? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Increased breakdown of glycogen to glucose
Increased heart rate and blood pressure

questions.explanation: Sympathetic response: Adrenaline release, Glucose release (energy), High HR/BP. Digestion stops and pupils dilate.
questions.hint: Getting ready to run.

questions.question: The enzyme ___BLANK___ is secreted by the kidneys in response to low blood pressure. It initiates the RAAS pathway.
questions.explanation: Renin converts Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I.
questions.hint: Sounds like 'Renal'.

questions.question: What is the name of the process where cell division results in an uncontrolled growth of abnormal cells?
questions.explanation: Neoplasia (new growth) or cancer involves uncontrolled mitosis.
questions.hint: Starts with 'N' or 'C'.

questions.question: Which component of the eye contains the photoreceptors (Rods and Cones)?
questions.explanation: The retina is the innermost nervous layer containing the light-sensitive cells.
questions.hint: Like the 'film' in a camera.

questions.question: Why is Type O Blood considered the 'Universal Donor'?

richContent.content:
Blood TypeAntigens on RBCAntibodies in Plasma
AAAnti-B
BBAnti-A
ABA and BNone
ONoneAnti-A and Anti-B

options.text: It has both A and B antigens
It has no antibodies in the plasma
It has NO antigens on the red blood cell surface to trigger a reaction
It clots faster than other types

questions.explanation: Type O RBCs lack antigens. Therefore, when injected into a recipient, the recipient's antibodies (Anti-A or Anti-B) have nothing to attack.
questions.hint: Look at the 'Antigens on RBC' column.
